segments.en: Linked Discourses 22
9. Senior Mendicants
87. With Vakkali

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā vakkali kumbhakāranivesane viharati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
segments.en: Now at that time Venerable Vakkali was staying in a potter’s shed, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vakkali upaṭṭhāke āmantesi:
segments.en: Then he addressed his carers,

segments.pli: “etha tumhe, āvuso, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatha:
segments.en: “Please, reverends, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

segments.pli: ‘vakkali, bhante, bhikkhu ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, so bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is sick, suffering, and gravely ill. He bows with his head to your feet.’
And then say:

segments.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena vakkali bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
segments.en: ‘Sir, please go to the mendicant Vakkali out of compassion.’”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato vakkalissa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They did as he asked.

segments.pli: “vakkali, bhante, bhikkhu ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, so bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati;
‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena vakkali bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.

segments.en: The Buddha consented in silence.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yenāyasmā vakkali tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robes, went to Venerable Vakkali.

segments.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā vakkali bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ. Disvāna mañcake samadhosi.
segments.en: Venerable Vakkali saw the Buddha coming off in the distance and tried to rise on his cot.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: But the Buddha said to him,
“It’s all right, Vakkali, don’t get up.
There are some seats spread out, I will sit there.”

segments.pli: Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane. Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: He sat on the seat spread out and said to Vakkali,

segments.pli: “kacci te, vakkali, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti?
segments.en: “Vakkali, I hope you’re keeping well; I hope you’re alright. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

segments.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ, na yāpanīyaṃ; bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, I’m not all right, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is apparent, not its fading.”

segments.pli: “Kacci te, vakkali, na kiñci kukkuccaṃ, na koci vippaṭisāro”ti?
segments.en: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”

segments.pli: “Taggha me, bhante, anappakaṃ kukkuccaṃ, anappako vippaṭisāro”ti.
segments.en: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”

segments.pli: “Kacci pana taṃ, vakkali, attā sīlato na upavadatī”ti?
segments.en: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”

segments.pli: “Na kho maṃ, bhante, attā sīlato upavadatī”ti.
segments.en: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”

segments.pli: “No ce kira taṃ, vakkali, attā sīlato upavadati; atha kiñca te kukkuccaṃ ko ca vippaṭisāro”ti?
segments.en: “In that case, Vakkali, why do you have remorse and regret?”

segments.pli: “Cirapaṭikāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitukāmo, natthi ca me kāyasmiṃ tāvatikā balamattā, yāvatāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyan”ti.
segments.en: “For a long time I’ve wanted to go and see the Buddha, but I was physically too weak.”

segments.pli: “Alaṃ, vakkali, kiṃ te iminā pūtikāyena diṭṭhena?
segments.en: “Enough, Vakkali! Why would you want to see this rotten body?

segments.pli: Yo kho, vakkali, dhammaṃ passati so maṃ passati;
segments.en: One who sees the teaching sees me.

segments.pli: yo maṃ passati so dhammaṃ passati.
segments.en: One who sees me sees the teaching.
Seeing the teaching, you see me.
Seeing me, you see the teaching.
What do you think, Vakkali?
Is form permanent or impermanent?”
“Impermanent, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
“Suffering, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
“No, sir.”
“Is feeling …
perception …
choices …
consciousness permanent or impermanent?”
“Impermanent, sir.” …
“So you should truly see …
Seeing this …
They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ iminā ovādena ovaditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena gijjhakūṭo pabbato tena pakkāmi.
segments.en: And then, after giving Venerable Vakkali this advice, the Buddha got up from his seat and went to the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vakkali acirapakkantassa bhagavato upaṭṭhāke āmantesi:
segments.en: Then Venerable Vakkali addressed his carers,

segments.pli: “etha maṃ, āvuso, mañcakaṃ āropetvā yena isigilipassaṃ kāḷasilā tenupasaṅkamatha.
segments.en: “Come on, reverends, lift my cot and take me to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili.

segments.pli: Kathañhi nāma mādiso antaraghare kālaṃ kattabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti?
segments.en: It’s unthinkable for one like me to die in an inhabited area!”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato vakkalissa paṭissutvā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ mañcakaṃ āropetvā yena isigilipassaṃ kāḷasilā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
segments.en: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants, and did as he asked.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tañca rattiṃ tañca divāvasesaṃ gijjhakūṭe pabbate vihāsi.
segments.en: Meanwhile, the Buddha spent the rest of that night and day on Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

segments.pli: Atha kho dve devatāyo abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu … pe … ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
segments.en: Then, late at night, two glorious deities, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: One deity said to him,
“Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is intent on liberation!”
And another deity said to him,
“He’ll definitely be well-freed!”
This is what those deities said.

segments.pli: Idaṃ vatvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṃsu.
segments.en: Then they bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right side, before vanishing right there.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

segments.pli: “etha tumhe, bhikkhave, yena vakkali bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā vakkaliṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadetha:
segments.en: “Come, mendicants, go to the mendicant Vakkali and tell him:

segments.pli: ‘Suṇāvuso tvaṃ, vakkali, bhagavato vacanaṃ dvinnañca devatānaṃ.
segments.en: ‘Vakkali, hear the word of the Buddha and two deities.

segments.pli: Imaṃ, āvuso, rattiṃ dve devatāyo abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
segments.en: Late last night, two glorious deities, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, āvuso, ekā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
segments.en: One deity said to him,
“Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is intent on liberation!”
And another deity said to him,

segments.pli: so hi nūna, bhante, suvimutto vimuccissatīti.
segments.en: “He’ll definitely be well-freed!”

segments.pli: Bhagavā ca taṃ, āvuso vakkali, evamāha—
segments.en: And the Buddha said,
“Do not fear, Vakkali,
do not fear!

segments.pli: Apāpakaṃ te maraṇaṃ bhavissati, apāpikā kālakiriyā’”ti.
segments.en: Your death will not be a bad one; your passing will not be a bad one.”’”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā vakkali tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” those monks replied. They went to Vakkali and said to him:
“Vakkali, hear the word of the Buddha and two deities.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vakkali upaṭṭhāke āmantesi:
segments.en: Then Vakkali addressed his carers,
“Please, reverends, help me off my cot.

segments.pli: Kathañhi nāma mādiso ucce āsane nisīditvā tassa bhagavato sāsanaṃ sotabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti.
segments.en: It’s unthinkable for one like me to listen to the Buddha’s instructions sitting on a high seat.”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato vakkalissa paṭissutvā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ mañcakā oropesuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants, and helped him off his cot.

segments.pli: “Imaṃ, āvuso, rattiṃ dve devatāyo abhikkantāya rattiyā … pe … ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
segments.en: They repeated what the Buddha had said.

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, āvuso, ekā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
Bhagavā ca taṃ, āvuso vakkali, evamāha:
Apāpakaṃ te maraṇaṃ bhavissati, apāpikā kālakiriyā’”ti.
“Tena hāvuso, mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatha:
segments.en: Vakkali said, “Well then, reverends, in my name bow with your head to the Buddha’s feet. Say to him:
‘Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
He bows with his head to your feet.’
And then say:
‘Form is impermanent.
I have no doubt of that.
I’m certain that what is impermanent is suffering.

segments.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmi.
segments.en: And I’m certain that I have no desire or greed or fondness for what is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.
Feeling is impermanent …

segments.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmi.

segments.en: Perception is impermanent …
Choices are impermanent …

segments.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmi.

segments.en: Consciousness is impermanent.
I have no doubt of that.
I’m certain that what is impermanent is suffering.

segments.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmī’”ti.
segments.en: And I’m certain that I have no desire or greed or fondness for what is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato vakkalissa paṭissutvā pakkamiṃsu.
segments.en: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied, and left.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vakkali acirapakkantesu tesu bhikkhūsu satthaṃ āharesi.
segments.en: And then, not long after those mendicants had left, Venerable Vakkali slit his wrists.

segments.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then those senior mendicants went up to the Buddha and told him Vakkali’s message.

segments.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmi.
Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmī’”ti.

segments.en: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
“Come, mendicants, let’s go to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili,
where Vakkali, the gentleman, slit his wrists.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” they replied.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ yena isigilipassaṃ kāḷasilā tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then the Buddha together with several mendicants went to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili.

segments.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ dūratova mañcake vivattakkhandhaṃ semānaṃ.
segments.en: The Buddha saw Vakkali off in the distance lying on his cot, having cast off the aggregates.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dhūmāyitattaṃ timirāyitattaṃ gacchateva purimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati pacchimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uttaraṃ disaṃ, gacchati dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uddhaṃ disaṃ, gacchati adho disaṃ, gacchati anudisaṃ.
segments.en: Now at that time a cloud of black smoke was moving east, west, north, south, above, below, and in-between.
The Buddha said to the mendicants,

segments.pli: “passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, etaṃ dhūmāyitattaṃ timirāyitattaṃ gacchateva purimaṃ disaṃ … pe … gacchati anudisan”ti.
segments.en: “Mendicants, do you see that cloud of black smoke moving east, west, north, south, above, below, and in-between?”
“Yes, sir.”

segments.pli: “Eso kho, bhikkhave, māro pāpimā vakkalissa kulaputtassa viññāṇaṃ samanvesati:
segments.en: “That’s Māra the Wicked searching for Vakkali’s consciousness, wondering:
‘Where is Vakkali’s consciousness established?’

segments.pli: Appatiṭṭhitena ca, bhikkhave, viññāṇena vakkali kulaputto parinibbuto”ti.
segments.en: But since his consciousness is not established, Vakkali is extinguished.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha,…

suttaplex.blurb: Venerable Vakkali is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, but says there is no point in seeing his physical body, as one who sees the Dhamma sees him. Later, Vakkali is taken to the Black Rock on Isigili, where he declares that he has no attachment to the aggregates, and takes his own life. The Buddha says that he had attained final extinguishment.
